captions.text:
Can you make water explode? Well, maybe not
water per-se, but with a simple technique,

we can turn one of the most abundant materials
on earth, into a highly explosive gas. In

this project we're building a generator that
uses electricity to convert this, into this.

For this project we're going to need some
stainless steel. I'm at a local fabrication

company, and not only do they have plenty
of scrap metal to choose from, they're even

willing to help me cut it to custom sizes.
A job that would have taken me hours with

a pair of tin snips and a hack saw, only takes
a matter of minutes with their equipment.

This is 20 gauge stainless steel, and this
hydraulic punch is being used to cut precise

holes in the tops and bottoms of the plates.
When finished, I have 12 plates measuring

3" x 6", 4 plates at 1 1/2" x 6", and three
1" connector bands that are 6", 4 1/2", and

3 1/4". A belt sander is perfect for smoothing
down the jagged edges around the hole, and

now it's time to head home and get to work.
We'll need these 4" ABS cleanout fittings,

3/8" poly tubing, as well as some scrap 4"
and 2" acrylic tubing I found at a plastics

company. When I peel the protective layer
from the plates, it reveals a beautiful and

attractive surface. But that's not what we
want for this project. Instead, we'll need

to hunt down some sandpaper. This is 100 grit,
and I'll place 2 plates in a diamond shape,

and sand from top to bottom, then rotate 90
degrees, and repeat. These scuff marks will

increase the surface area on the plates and
increase the efficiency of the generator.

Ok, I've finished off both sides of the plates
and you can see the criss-cross pattern etched

into the metal. The 1 1/2" plates are sanded
as well, but the 3 connector bands are not.

Alright, it's time to cut this acrylic tubing
to size, so I'm using a chop saw to trim this

edge smooth, then I'll measure 7", and cut
nice and slowly so that I don't chip the plastic.

As the blade cuts, the friction also helps
heat the plastic, leaving a fairly clear edge.

After I've cut 5" of the 2" tubing, it's time
to make some connections. With some gentle

persuasion, I've managed to fit the large
acrylic tube into the clean out adaptor, but

before we push them together, let's add a
liberal amount of clear silicone caulking

all around the outer base. This will also
go on the inside being very careful not to get

any silicone on the threads. Now we can use
a rubber hammer to tap the tubing all the

way into place, and clean up the excess silicone.
Paper towel works well, and in a few minutes,

it's all cleaned up. We can flip this over,
and repeat the process of attaching, caulking

this part, and this part, tapping into place,
and cleaning up the excess. While I'm in the

mood for cleaning, I'll use my adhesive remover
to assist in clearing off the UPC stickers,

then give everything one final wipe down.
I'm going to seal the bottom with a 4" ABS

clean-out plug and some ABS cement. The gooey
black cement is applied to the threads of

both parts, and then I'll use this piece of
scrap wood from my "Solar Scorcher Frame"

project to help screw it in tight. The excess
is removed, and we can let it sit here to

cure. While that's drying, let's get to work
on making the bubbler. I want to attach this

1/4" 90 degree elbow to the cap, so when the
stickers are removed, I'll grab my 1/2 drill

bit, and a tap. The hole is drilled in the
center, then tapped at 18 thread, just before

adding pipe tape to the elbow adaptor, and
screwing into place. When that's tight, and

I've repeated the exact same process with
the other cap, I'm happy to see they fit snug

onto my acrylic tubing. It looks unfinished
though, so I'm going to use these top pieces

from 2 trap adaptors to slide onto the tubing
first, and now when I add the cap, they screw

together giving this piece a clean professional
look. Ok now it's time to work on the generator

plates. Similar to the bubbler caps, I'm drilling
a 1/2" hole into the top of the 4" clean-out

plug. When that's tapped to 18 thread, we
can add pipe tape to a 3/8" swivel elbow and

screw that into place. You can see this swivels
360 degrees, and that's mostly for convenience.

Using a 5/16" drill bit, I'll make holes on
either side of the cap, and these will be

for attaching the generator plates. I cut
this hole a little close to the edge, but

no problem. My belt sander easily rounded
the edges, and now it's a perfect fit. Next,

I'll mark the two smaller bands at about 2
3/4", and use my bench vise and a rubber hammer

to bend them to 90 angles. The 6" piece is
marked at 1 3/4" and 4 1/4", then bent into

a "U" shape. A 5/16" course thread nylon bolt
is cut into two pieces 4" long. I'll get some

nylon washers ready, and add two stainless
steel jam nuts, to the end of each bolt. The

bolts are fitted with two of the connector
straps, and one of the smaller plates, then

a plastic washer is added on each bolt. These
washers are 3/4" diameter, and about 0.06"

thick. Another 1 1/2" plate is added, and
secured with a nut on each bolt, and now the

big plates can go on. I'm stacking these in
the order of plate, washers, plate, nuts,

and repeating until I've got a total of 8
plates in place. This is the center of the

generator, and the other connector strap is
added at the top and secured with another

nut. I'll add one more nut to the bottom to
compensate for the gap, and then get back

to my routine of adding plate, washers, plate,
nuts, until I run out of big plates. The two

smaller plates are added last, and now all
we need to do is trim down the bolt ends to

about 1/2" so we can snap the bottom connector
into place, add a nut, and tighten. The other

bolt also gets a finishing nut, and then is
trimmed down, and now we just need to turn

the generator around and move these screws
so that we can tighten the inner ones. The

generator plates are done, and looking very
nice, so let's connect them up to the 4" plug.

To do that, I'll add a nut to a 5/16" x 2"
stainless steel bolt and push them through

the hole in the right connector strap. This
1/4" washer is stainless steel on one side,

and rubber on the other, and I'll push that
down the bolt with the rubber side up. That's

all repeated on the left side, and now the
cap is placed over the bolts. Two more washers

are added, this time with rubber side down,
and secured with another nut. Using an allen

wrench, the nut is tightened securely, and
then a few more nuts and metal washers are

added to the posts for convenience. This piece
is finished. I'm really happy with it, and

when I dry-fit it into the casing and screw
it into position, I'm starting to get excited.

We're going to need a way to secure the bubbler
to the side, so using some leftovers from

the 2" pipe, I'll very carefully cut two 3/4"
thick circles, then use a wood 2x4 to hold

the piece flat while I trim off the top. What
I've done is created a clip for our bubbler

and you can see it clips easily onto the tube
and holds firmly in place. The other circle

is cut, and a belt sander used to match the
pieces as closely as possible. I've got some

left over acrylic rod from my "Fire Piston"
project, and I'll cut off 2 pieces about 1

1/2" long. I'll use some acrylic glue to secure
the clips to the connector rods, and after

2 minutes they're firm, but will still take
over 2 days to fully cure. While those are

setting, I'll use scissors to cut my poly
tube at 20", and another piece at 2". The

2" piece connects to a one-way check valve,
and gets inserted into the swivel elbow. This

will prevent anything from flowing back into
the generator. The 20" tube goes on the other

end of the valve, and then connects to one
of the bubbler elbows. It looks like we're

ready to attach the clips to the body, so
let's use the bubbler body as a form for spacing

the clips, and with the generator on it's
side, find where it balances. That looks good

there, so acrylic glue is added to the clips
and replaced on the body. When it sets, I'll

use a little more glue in the gaps, and remove
the bubbler to let it cure. In the mean time,

we can ready 6 cups of distilled water, and
some flakes of potassium hydroxide. 4 Teaspoons

of flakes will act as a catalyst to help the
electricity flow, so when they're stirred

in, we can open the generator body, and attach
a coffee filter to filter the fluid into the

super cleaned casing. The filter is removed
and thread tape is added to the cap, then

the generator plates are slowly inserted into
the solution, and screwed in water tight.

To finish up, we can remove the top cap from
the bubbler, add some water, and screw it

back together. The remainder of the poly tube
is attached to the bubbler elbow, and there

it is! A sexy looking hydroxy generator! This
system produces an extremely powerful OxyHydrogen

gas. Running on 2 car batteries, it will make
about 5 liters per minute, and when the gas

is used, it simply turns back into water.
The amount of water already in this system

is enough to produce thousands and thousands
of liters of fuel. Some people say this is

the fuel of the future. Whether or not that's
true, the amount of power in the gas, is humbling.

Well there's how to build a simple water/fuel
converter. If you liked this project, perhaps

you'll like some of my others. Check them
out at www.thekingofrandom.com

title: Water To Fuel Converter - (Explosive Gas by Electrolysis)

comments.author: BonanaSquid

comments.text:
HHO gas in my opinion is much better than petrol or diesel. You can use 
itdirectly in a petrol engine with no modifications and if there is a car 
crash, the hydrogen is likely to float away from the car before it can 
explode (even if there is a small chance of ignition) due to it being about 
one fifteenth of the weight of air. In total, the ratio of the amount of 
energy from burning the fuel to the amount of energy to make the fuel is 
much higher with HHO gas than petrol or diesel, as the only energy required 
for it is to split the water, whereas with petrol and diesel, there is 
energy required for extracting the crude oil from the ground, seperating 
the oil in a fractioning column (requiring huge amounts of heat) and then 
purifying the fuel to reduce the amount of particles that would be 
unburned. Water does not need to be purified, in fact SHOULDN'T be purified 
for use as a fuel. Thank you for reading, this would get 6/6 on a GCSE QWC 
question haha. But take this seriously, please. What people mean by a "free 
energy" source is merely just a much more efficient source than is widely 
used in the world.﻿

I urge people to be careful. Grant used stainless steel as electrodes in 
his generator, which contains chromium.  Occasionally, this will react with 
oxygen to form Hexavalent chromium, which is toxic and carcinegenic. Please 
be careful with your experimentation.﻿

comments.author: TheRatesMusic

comments.text:
+Lajos Winkler I gave examples of where this is already being done.  That's 
realism isn't it?

Of course getting it from fossil fuels isn't cheap.  It's cheaper to just 
burn the fuel. Turning it into H is just more steps to get back to the same 
thing.  Nature has already done the conversion when the ancient plant 
extracted hydrogen from water via sunlight, leaving behind hydrocarbons 
that we go to great lengths to find and dig up.  Then we have to use the 
extremely inefficient method of converting the hydrocarbon into heat 
energy, then mechanical to end up with electricity.  It is only because 
fossil fuels have such high energy concentrations that this method is 
worthwhile.

Water does have to be converted before it's useful.  That takes energy and 
the laws of thermodynamics say we'll never get back what we put in.  With 
solar we don't care if we get back what we put in because what we put in is 
free and unlimited in supply.

In the long run free-but-slow trumps expensive-but-fast.  The graph would 
be two exponential curves heading in opposite directions.
comments.author: TheRatesMusic

comments.text:
+TheRatesMusic Hydrogen economy is a waste of time and resources. Storage 
IS difficult and the gas is an insanely powerful ozone depletant. Also, 
almost all of the hydrogen today is made from fossil fuels. Even that 
doesn't make it cheap. Playing with electrolysis is way more expensive, and 
plans to run it by solar panels is laughable. More realism wouldn't harm 
you.
comments.author: Lajos Winkler

comments.text:
+Lajos Winkler Several companies have already built variations on this 
method. Hyundai has developed a self contained hydrogen re-fueling station 
which uses this principle and is installing them in Australia to power the 
hydrogen fuel cell cars it wants to sell. Honda has a unit which will power 
a home by extracting hydrogen from natural gas via solar. Yes it doesn't 
use water but it shows hydrogen storage isn't an issue. Theoretically you 
would just need more solar panels to run it on water. Several universities 
including MIT are working on similar systems which use catalysts (iron 
oxide) to help break the water making the process more efficient. Other 
companies are using nano particles to mimic photosynthesis while another 
has developed a method to use solar to convert waste CO2 into methane.


I'm not some greenie or dreaming of a utopia, I'm a pragmatist and believer 
in the market. There's too much money to be made and meanwhile technology 
advances exponentially. Eventually they are bound to coincide.
comments.author: TheRatesMusic

comments.text:
+TheRatesMusic How would you store hydrogen? It's usually stored by 
pressurizing it to enormous pressures like 200 bar and that requires lots 
of energy. I'll say again - it's not like engineers and scientists haven't 
tried this before. It's useless. Solar panels are so incredibly pathetic 
sources for such tasks. There's a reason why people invest in batteries and 
fuel cells are for highly specialized purposes like spaceships.
comments.author: Lajos Winkler

comments.text:
+Lajos Winkler ah sorry, I wasn't talking about powering a car. I was 
thinking of using fuel cells to turn it back into electricity. Converting 
it to hydrogen allows you to store the energy without batteries. You could 
do it on a large scale, especially in Australia where we have a lot of flat 
sunny desert land near the coast (water supply).
comments.author: TheRatesMusic

comments.text:
+TheRatesMusic Creating hydrogen onboard to temporarily store energy means 
losing energy by extending the energy transformation path. Also, it's wet 
hydrogen. Engine doesn't like wet things and certainly not hydrogen because 
it ruins the metal by making it brittle.
There is absolutely no need for this. If it was viable, you can be sure the 
large automobile companies would be all over it. But it's not.
At best, we have battery storage with electrical cars which are beneficial 
only if the energy producer is beneficial. For example, France which 
produces most of its energy using nuclear fission would be a good 
candidate. USA, with tons of its CO2 crapping coal power plants would be a 
disaster if it would turn to electric cars.
comments.author: Lajos Winkler

comments.author: Valeska Vesuvius

comments.text:
+Lajos Winkler Your reply made me decide to look into it, here is what I 
found.

Hydrogen sells for between 2 and 4 dollars per kilogram (1000 grams)
Unit makes 5 ltrs per minute and let's say we run it 8 hours per day.
Hydrogen weighs 4.12 grams per 50 litres (1 atmosphere, room temp).
Solar panels are rated for 25 years but let's say 15.

That's 8 x 60 x 5 = 2400 litres per day.
2400 / 50 x 4.12 = 198 grams per day x 365 = 72,270 or about 72kg per year.

72kg x 15 yrs = 1080 kg x $3/kg = $3240 over 15 years.

In Australia $1895 will get you a 1.5kw system including inverter, which is 
enough to power a small home. $5000 will get you a 3kw system.  $161,000 
will get you a 100kw system. Should be cheaper in the US and cheaper again 
direct from China.

Now consider
That model in the video is tiny and inefficient. 
The prices above are retail price and include install.
The price of panels is dropping while efficiency increases.
Demand for hydrogen will likely rise.

Don't forget the added cost for hydrogen storage

I wouldn't say it was crazy to look into it further, but that's just me.
comments.author: TheRatesMusic

comments.text:

storage problem. My hydrogen idea (further down the thread) is, I think, a

breaking sea water into hydrogen for storage.  Then generate electricity 
via fuel cells as needed.  As fresh water  is the by product it also acts 
as a desalination plant.

comments.text:
It isn't one of the most abundant materials on Earth though. Look up 3D 
renders of all the water in the world curled into a ball, and you'll find 
it's way smaller than what remains. Furthermore, only 1% of that is fresh 
and drinkable, so it's actually quite precious. The misconception stems 
from the fact that most of the Earth's surface is covered in water, but 
surface and volume are two very different things :)﻿

comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
Great inflation is not a speculation. It is part of a theory. It has tons 
of math behind it and empirical observation which can't be explained by 
other means, at least not now.
That's how science works - it builds evidence and, as limit functions which 
approach to 1, it crawls towards 100% certainty, but inherently can't reach 
it because it's always opened for more evidence. That's its power.
comments.author: Lajos Winkler

comments.text:
And the great inflation? While it's a great idea, it too is only 
speculation.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
I'm really trying to show you that if we can't even figure out things like 
that, then how can we positively say for sure we are right? There are many 
things that are based off observation. Those are correct. A law is 
something that never changes, but things like super-positioning are nothing 
more than our best guess.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
My point was that we really can't prove anything beyond a shadow of a 
doubt. We can't even figure out how a particle is a wave and vice versa...
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
+jake stockton Don't you see how you're holding two opposite opinions? 
First you say it's speculation, then you say "yes, we could suspend 
gravity". Sorry, but that's just bullshit.
Not only there is absolutely no empirical or theoretical or hypothetical 
basis for your claim, all motion does not stop. It's a common knowledge.
comments.author: Lajos Winkler

comments.text:
+Mr.chang cooler All movement does not stop. There's always some movement 
due to quantum mechanical effects. Go to Wikipedia and search for zero 
point energy. That's the lowest possible, unavoidable level of energy all 
systems have and below which you can not go. Also for the same reasons, 
it's not possible to tap it It's kind of a common knowledge in physics. Not 
only do the subatomic particles never stop jiggling, but the atoms and 
molecules themselves don't, either.
comments.author: Lajos Winkler

comments.text:
"IF" we could reach absolute zero my proposition could very likely be 
tested... but we can't, and the energy required to create it would be 
infinite. If we had that much energy, then yes, we could suspend gravity 
until movement began again. The problem is: even observing a particle in 
that state would create motion, and without observation, there is only 
speculation.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
+Lajos Winkler Absolute zero cannot exist, and he is right. All movement 
stops. And finally, a billionth of a kelvin =/= 0 kelvin.
comments.author: Mr.chang cooler

comments.text:
+jake stockton What fools would believe in perpetual motion in 2015? Damn 
it, does nobody know the first law of thermodynamics? Or do they just sit 
in their little ignorance bubbles and deny it? And what idiot would 
advertise the violation of the first law of thermodynamics when it is not 
possible?
comments.author: Mr.chang cooler

comments.text:
That is absolute bullshit. Atomic movement does not stop at zero kelvin and 
particle interaction does exist. If all atomic interactions stopped at zero 
kelvin, we'd see matter being ruined in laboratory experiments when it's 
cooled down to billionths of a kelvin.
Where did you hear this crap?
comments.author: Lajos Winkler

comments.text:
+D.J. Md Gravity is the result of movement relative to its position to 
another object. If you cool two sub-atomic particles down to absolute zero, 
all atomic movement stops. This results in the two particles not being able 
to interact with each other. They lose static charge and their 
gravitational fields. With subatomic particle movement, ( when in their 
normal states), particles move towards each other creating energy without 
the parasitic energy loss upon any given object. In essence, a particle 
doesn't have to shed an electron for gravity to work. this is free energy.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
+jake stockton think about that one. Gravity is not free energy. (we don't 
even know what it really is). Just like we don't fully understand 
electricity we just use it. I always loved my professors who asked a 
question in lecture. Students answering their best guess. My answer was 
usually "we don't know" and not that I don't know. but "science does not 
know the answer yet"
comments.author: D.J. Md

comments.text:
+jake stockton Yes, there is no free energy.  With some forethought, this 
could provide a means to store energy.  Yes, there is an efficiency loss.
comments.author: Michael Nunnery

comments.text:
The only true form of free energy is gravity itself. Gravity pulls 
subatomic particles together to produce mass. An increase in mass produces 
heat. Heat is energy. When mass reaches a threshold, it starts to produce 
large amount of static electricity. This disrupts the covalent bonds to 
form larger atoms. When larger atoms form, electrons are shed and converted 
to photons. This is called fusion. At no point during this process is 
energy created or destroyed. It's purely transformed into something else.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
In reality, there is no such thing as "true" free energy. Energy is only 
converted from one form to another.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
+TheGodWaffle if you could trap 100% of the heat (impossible) and turn it 
back into electricity, you would only break even. In that case, it's still 
not free energy.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text:
+TheGodWaffle the amount of energy input into the system to produce 
hydrogen is more than the energy that can be extracted from the hydrogen. 
The loss is minimal, but it is there. The loss is through heat conductance 
through the wires.
comments.author: jake stockton

comments.text: +TheGodWaffle It's not free fuel.

comments.text:
I hear a lot of comparison between this fuel source to the standard 
gasoline fuel source. The fact that you can achieve any sort of combustion 
from water electrolysis is something to research in my opinion. It may not 
be the answer, but a good step in a better direction. Using in a typical 
internal combustion engine also might not be a ideal design for it it's 
use. Radical ideas and concepts often yield great results. Just haven't 
seen it yet.﻿

comments.text:
So the neutral plates act as a bridge for the electrons to flow through, 
dividing the voltage between all the plates and decreasing the resistance 
created by the water, thus increasing the current according to I=V/R?﻿
comments.author: Niko Aaltonen

comments.text: Don't give up 💔💗
comments.author: Mohammad Awal

comments.text:
The neutral plates act as a voltage divider to make the system more 
efficient. If I remember correctly, water start to electrolyze at 1.2 volts 
and peaks around 2volts. Any voltage higher than that is just wasted into 
heat.

Since the car battery is 12volts,  typically people will put 6 plates (4 
neutral plates in between).  It will divide the 12volts into 2 volts each 
plate roughly. The higher the voltage, the more plates you put in to keep 
each plate around 2volts.
